Gonna Copypaste some notes from a reply on the build this mouse was used in below:
A note is that if you prefer to Shut Down instead of putting your PC to Sleep, you may have to play around with your USB settings to get the Charging Dock to stay on while your PC is off (just go to your Mouse in the 'Hardware & Devices' section of the Control Panel and check "allow this device to wake up the computer"). You can tell what Charge level the mouse has when it's docked as the Razer logo RGB shows a certain color:
Solid Green = Fully charged
Strobe Green = Mostly charged
Strobe Yellow = Medium battery
Strobe Red = Low battery

This is an excellent and affordable mouse with versatile functionality for a workstation, gaming rig, or both! The design is sleek, modern, stylish, and adaptable to all hand sizes. The scroll-wheel can be toggled between free-spinning infinite scroll, and "click-scrolling." The thumb rest shelf has easy access to the three side hotkeys. The weight is adjustable with included insertable metal plates. The design does include a lot of crevices, so it can be a challenge to keep it clean of crumbs, pet hair, and whatever else; however a recessed laser sensor ensures continuous accuracy of input readings.
Logitech Gaming software allows custom programming of the six mouse hotkey buttons and even the middle mouse button. Three distinct profiles are saved internally on the mouse itself, so you can keep your settings even if you switch between rigs. Each profile can be set to different hotkeys, macros, RGB coloration, and DPI sensitivity. Beyond the six hotkeys (*recommended reserving one for quick profile switching,) the "G-Shift" function allows a second set of programmable commands available while simultaneously holding down the user-programmed G-Shift hotkey. Profiles have up to five DPI settings each that can be quick-shifted or toggled between with a hotkey.
Durability and build quality are both high, and the cord is braided with a cloth wrap. It is unlikely any part will break within the mouse's lifetime.
There is nothing I can't recommend about this mouse, other than keeping the surface clean. It is a great customizable mouse for anybody- students, office drones, gamers, and even the most casual users will benefit from the Logitech G502, and the base model is affordable! You don't have to be a competitive gamer or professional streamer to justify purchasing this mouse.

Also, unlike some of my other RGB devices, the mouse retains its settings when the computer is restarted or awakes from sleep mode. For example, my AIO uses NZXT CAM for its RGB, and it is completely hit or miss whether the RGB decides to turn on when I start up. This might be the best mouse I’ve ever owned. Great color, cool lighting effects, and it’s especially amazing when paired with the docking station.
Years ago, I had the first version of the Razer Mamba, and it came with a dock that looked like a podium. Back then, charging was done through contact pins, so you had to place the mouse correctly — not difficult, but still required a bit of care. It also had the option to work either wirelessly through the dock or with a special-shaped cable that plugged directly into the mouse.
Now, things are so much better. The docking station magnetically snaps the mouse into place, just like Apple’s MagSafe. 😄 The dongle is hidden under the bottom cover of the mouse, so you can take it with you, plug it into any device, and keep using the mouse wirelessly — no need to carry the dock around. There’s also Bluetooth support, and any USB-C cable works fine for charging (unless it’s too bulky to fit).
The only weird thing is the protruding side button. It’s not recognized as a separate button — you can only assign it to mimic a keypress or macro (or anything available in the Razer app). But this makes it impossible to use properly in games.
By “properly” I mean having it recognized as something like Mouse6, instead of being treated as some random key you’ve assigned to it, leaving you wondering why it feels so inconvenient. 😬

I'm gonna be real sad when I can't use this mouse anymore. 6 tactile side buttons in a rectangle, on-board memory, unlockable scroll wheel, big and heavy. Literally a perfect mouse. The only thing out there that's similar is the Naga Pro 2 but that thing's $150 minimum.
Bit of advice to anyone with a wireless Logitech mouse: If you can get away with it, get Ghub off your computer. I don't know why but this mouse's battery life literally tripled or more when I saved my mouse buttons in Ghub to the on-board memory and uninstalled Ghub.

Great wireless mouse, with Logitech's amazing lightspeed wireless connection. I adore all the buttons on the mouse, actually helps a lot both in productivity and gaming. The only thing I DESPISE about this mouse is Logitech's terrible G-Hub software, its atrocious and hard to use.

Over 1000 hours of gaming use, I love this mouse and love its design, completely reprogrammable. Any other mouse feels weird to use because I'm so used to it, it's nice that it uses an AA battery because it lasts so long I've only changed it 3 times, the dpi settings on the mouse are also nice for precision. I wish this mouse would never wear out or break. I've had this mouse for a little over 3 years now btw, I'm gonna be heart broken when it dies of old age and lots of use.

A bang for the buck mouse for MMO, simulator, and complicated games.
The downside is the poor durability of the switches.
I have used the G503 for a lot of years on my old computer so I got the newer version for the new computer. Works the same and has the 6 thumb buttons.

Meh. All I want is a simple mouse that offers a click button for hyper scroll. I don't need all the extra side buttons and fancy junk. So this was the compromise to use the reliable "Lightspeed" connection and have hyper scroll.
Overall though, I think Logitech has lost a lot of their footing and every single newer product I have purchased from them has been total junk. It's been 0 for 4 products so I gave up. Actually kind of shocked this mouse is still working, but the flap on the thumb side is loose.
The Logitech software is very annoying but once you have it set up with works great.

Best mouse for MOBA. Decent quality. The plastic quality is not as good as G602 (old model) but wcyd. Theres an issue with the on board chip of this mouse. If you plan to use this mouse with no software it might bug out on you and click twice for every click you do. I'm not sure whats causes this to happen but if you run the software everything works perfectly. It has bluetooth and 2.5GH USB reciever so you can switch between 2 computers if you hold the wifi button for 1 sec.

I love the overall feel of the mouse itself, and I like that it's wireless. However, I'm on my 2nd G604 mouse. Luckily, Logitech warranty is great. The side buttons make me continue to use this and non of the others.

Since my g903 burnt down inside literally I wanted something fresh, I was already failiar with the G502 shape and the hero sensor from 903 but I wanted somthing different. I came up on this and It feels like a more refinded version of the g502. I had one issue wherethe right click was rubbing on something which got alleviated within a couple weeks

Drag clicking without tape has a learning curve, but everything else is great.

name: SteelSeries Rival 650 Wireless Wireless Optical Mouse
comments:
Had a SteelSeries Rival 500 before which I loved but wanted to go for something wireless. This seemed like a logical choice and has so far been every bit as good as I'd hoped. I cannot tell any difference whatsoever in terms of lag when it's plugged in compared to when it's not, which is all I can say really!
For the price (still available the right side of £50) you can't go wrong.

its not the lightest out there, but i like it, i like heavy mice. Only complaint would be the side rubber pieces, they seem to fall off after maybe a year of use. To fix it you can glue them back on like i did.

Beautiful mouse, clean RGB design, great controlling software and battery lasts days (for my usage). Fits my hand really well and the adjustable weights is a nice touch. Controlling software and DPI/Profile settings are great for all types of games.
Steelseries, switched to them after using Razer for years but noticed that quality decreased. Very happy with the change.
Great wireless mouse at an acceptable price.
No delay, perfect weight

This is a good option for people who enjoy having a wireless mouse, and also being able to adjust the weights on it as well. It enjoys having the ability to be personalized in many ways through SteelSeries Engine 3, but keep in mind the RGB if you're always running wireless.
